editorial:
First, if , the transformation is trivially feasible. Beyond this
trivial case, let us consider the necessary conditions: The initial
state must allow at least one valid move. The target state must allow at
least one valid move. For every connected component, the number of
stones in the initial state must match the number of stones in the
target state. If a connected component is a bipartite graph, then after
a coloring of the graph, the number of stones in each part must also
satisfy corresponding constraints. We can represent a node as two
separate nodes: and , corresponding to states reachable in even and odd
steps, respectively.For an undirected edge , create directed edges
between and , as well as between and .Using this transformation: It is
sufficient to enumerate whether the target state is reached on an even
or odd step. For each connected component, count the number of stones
and verify that the condition is satisfied. The bipartite graph
constraint is inherently handled within this framework, eliminating the
need for special-case treatment. The first two conditions, ensuring that
the initial and target states allow at least one valid move, can be
verified using bipartite graph matching. If a valid matching exists, the
conditions are satisfied.Time Complexity: , where is the number of nodes
and is the number of edges.It can be shown that the above conditions are
not only necessary but also sufficient. By satisfying these conditions,
it is guaranteed that a valid transformation from to can be
constructed.This is a simpler, non-constructive proof. Below is a brief
outline of the proof idea. Since this proof doesn’t provide much help
for the construction part, some details are omitted.The problem can be
easily formulated as a network flow problem. You can construct a layered
graph where each layer represents one step of stone movement, and the
flow represents the movement of stones. Determining whether the stones
can move from the initial state to the target state is equivalent to
checking whether the flow is saturated. Let represent the number of
stones. According to the Max-flow Min-cut Theorem, we need to consider
whether there exists a cut with a capacity smaller than .If we sort all
the cut edges by their layer indices, there must exist two adjacent cut
edges whose layers, or their distance from the source or sink, exceed .
To disconnect the graph, one of these two regions must fully disconnect
the graph. Otherwise, after layers, the graph will remain connected.
However, since there exists a valid matching between the initial and
target states, it is possible to repeatedly move along this matching.
This ensures that there exists a flow of size from the source or sink to
any layer, meaning that the graph cannot be disconnected using fewer
than edges. In the graph after splitting the nodes, if we combine the
matching edges from and , we obtain a structure consisting of chains and
cycles. Note that for any cycle, the and edges alternate, meaning we can
always adjust the matching of in this cycle to make it identical to .
Afterward, we can find a spanning tree among the remaining edges. This
spanning tree still satisfies both the existence of matching and
connectivity conditions. Moreover, all stones in and (after coloring the
graph with black and white) will reside on the same layer.For trees, it
seems straightforward to move stones outward for subtrees with more
stones and inward for subtrees with fewer stones. However, due to the
constraint that each step must involve movement, deadlock situations may
arise, making it less trivial.For example, consider the following
scenario: After the first move, shifts to positions and . If we only
consider the number of stones in the subtrees of and or simply match
based on the shortest distance, the stones might return to and , leading
to a deadlock. The correct sequence of moves should be , , then , and
finally .Since and are symmetric, a meet-in-the-middle approach can be
applied, where we simultaneously consider both and and aim to transform
them into identical states. First find the matching for and . The idea
is to identify the "outermost" matching edge (the definition of
"outermost" will be formalized below). WLOG, we assume it is in . Then,
locate the nearest matching edge in relative to . Move the stones from
to the corresponding nodes in . Once they reach , let them move back and
forth between and . For the remaining unmatched nodes in , let them
oscillate along their own matching edges for the first two steps. If the
"outermost" matching edge is in , we can perform the corresponding
operations in reverse order. The explanation of how it works: First,
since we are choosing the nearest matching edge in , and the remaining
stones move along their matching edges for the first two steps. The
remaining stones will not meet the path corresponding to . Otherwise, it
would contradict the definition of "nearest". After moving to , the
stones will repeatedly move along the matching edge until the end of the
process. This means becomes impassable for subsequent moves. Therefore,
we require this edge to be "outermost," meaning that after removing
these two nodes, the remaining parts of and must still be connected. To
find the "outermost" edge, we can iteratively remove the leaf nodes of
the graph (nodes with degree at most 1). The first matching edge where
both nodes are removed is the "outermost" edge. Note that this
"outermost" criterion must consider both and , taking the "outermost"
edge among all matches in and . For the remaining stones, since we
ensure the process does not encounter this path or , the problem reduces
to a subproblem, which can be solved using the same method.This approach
takes two steps each time and removes one matching edge. If the tree has
nodes, the number of matching edges will not exceed , so we can solve
the problem in at most steps.Time complexity: .Note: The bound of is
tight. For example, consider a chain with an additional triangular loop
at the tail. If the goal is to move from to , at least one stone must
traverse the triangular loop to change its parity. This requires at
least steps.
name: H2. Kevin and Stones  Hard Version
statement:
Kevin has an undirected graph with n vertices and m edges. Initially,
some vertices contain stones, which Kevin wants to move to new
positions. Kevin can perform the following operation: For each stone at
u_i, select a neighboring vertex v_i. Simultaneously move each stone
from u_i to its corresponding v_i. At any time, each vertex can contain
stone.Determine whether a valid sequence of operations exists that moves
the stones from the initial state to the target state. Output a valid
sequence of operations with no more than 2n moves if one exists. It can
be proven that if a valid sequence exists, a valid sequence with no more
than 2n moves exists.
solutions:
#include <algorithm>#include <array>#include <bitset>#include <cassert>#include <chrono>#include <climits>#include <cmath>#include <complex>#include <cstring>#include <functional>#include <iomanip>#include <iostream>#include <map>#include <numeric>#include <queue>#include <random>#include <set>#include <vector>using namespace std; using ll = long long;using db = long double;  // or double, if TL is tightusing str = string;      // yay python! // pairsusing pi = pair<int, int>;using pl = pair<ll, ll>;using pd = pair<db, db>;#define mp make_pair#define f first#define s second #define tcT template <class T#define tcTU tcT, class U// ^ lol this makes everything look weird but I'll try ittcT > using V = vector<T>;tcT, size_t SZ > using AR = array<T, SZ>;using vi = V<int>;using vb = V<bool>;using vl = V<ll>;using vd = V<db>;using vs = V<str>;using vpi = V<pi>;using vpl = V<pl>;using vpd = V<pd>; // vectors#define sz(x) int(size(x))#define bg(x) begin(x)#define all(x) bg(x), end(x)#define rall(x) rbegin(x), rend(x)#define sor(x) sort(all(x))#define rsz resize#define ins insert#define pb push_back#define eb emplace_back#define ft front()#define bk back() #define lb lower_bound#define ub upper_boundtcT > int lwb(const V<T> &a, const T &b) { return int(lb(all(a), b) - bg(a)); }tcT > int upb(const V<T> &a, const T &b) { return int(ub(all(a), b) - bg(a)); } // loops#define FOR(i, a, b) for (int i = (a); i < (b); ++i)#define F0R(i, a) FOR(i, 0, a)#define ROF(i, a, b) for (int i = (b)-1; i >= (a); --i)#define R0F(i, a) ROF(i, 0, a)#define rep(a) F0R(_, a)#define each(a, x) for (auto &a : x) const int MOD = 998244353;  // 1e9+7;const int MX = (int)2e5 + 5;const ll BIG = 1e18;  // not too close to LLONG_MAXconst db PI = acos((db)-1);const int dx[4]{1, 0, -1, 0}, dy[4]{0, 1, 0, -1};  // for every grid problem!!mt19937 rng(0);template <class T> using pqg = priority_queue<T, vector<T>, greater<T>>; // bitwise ops// also see https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Other-Builtins.htmlconstexpr int pct(int x) { return __builtin_popcount(x); }  // # of bits setconstexpr int bits(int x) {  // assert(x >= 0); // make C++11 compatible until	                         // USACO updates ...	return x == 0 ? 0 : 31 - __builtin_clz(x);}  // floor(log2(x))constexpr int p2(int x) { return 1 << x; }constexpr int msk2(int x) { return p2(x) - 1; } ll cdiv(ll a, ll b) {	return a / b + ((a ^ b) > 0 && a % b);}  // divide a by b rounded upll fdiv(ll a, ll b) {	return a / b - ((a ^ b) < 0 && a % b);}  // divide a by b rounded down tcT > bool ckmin(T &a, const T &b) {	return b < a ? a = b, 1 : 0;}  // set a = min(a,b)tcT > bool ckmax(T &a, const T &b) {	return a < b ? a = b, 1 : 0;}  // set a = max(a,b) tcTU > T fstTrue(T lo, T hi, U f) {	++hi;	assert(lo <= hi);  // assuming f is increasing	while (lo < hi) {  // find first index such that f is true		T mid = lo + (hi - lo) / 2;		f(mid) ? hi = mid : lo = mid + 1;	}	return lo;}tcTU > T lstTrue(T lo, T hi, U f) {	--lo;	assert(lo <= hi);  // assuming f is decreasing	while (lo < hi) {  // find first index such that f is true		T mid = lo + (hi - lo + 1) / 2;		f(mid) ? lo = mid : hi = mid - 1;	}	return lo;}tcT > void remDup(vector<T> &v) {  // sort and remove duplicates	sort(all(v));	v.erase(unique(all(v)), end(v));}tcTU > void safeErase(T &t, const U &u) {	auto it = t.find(u);	assert(it != end(t));	t.erase(it);} inline namespace IO {#define SFINAE(x, ...)                                                         \	template <class, class = void> struct x : std::false_type {};              \	template <class T> struct x<T, std::void_t<__VA_ARGS__>> : std::true_type {} SFINAE(DefaultI, decltype(std::cin >> std::declval<T &>()));SFINAE(DefaultO, decltype(std::cout << std::declval<T &>()));SFINAE(IsTuple, typename std::tuple_size<T>::type);SFINAE(Iterable, decltype(std::begin(std::declval<T>()))); template <auto &is> struct Reader {	template <class T> void Impl(T &t) {		if constexpr (DefaultI<T>::value) is >> t;		else if constexpr (Iterable<T>::value) {			for (auto &x : t) Impl(x);		} else if constexpr (IsTuple<T>::value) {			std::apply([this](auto &...args) { (Impl(args), ...); }, t);		} else static_assert(IsTuple<T>::value, "No matching type for read");	}	template <class... Ts> void read(Ts &...ts) { ((Impl(ts)), ...); }}; template <class... Ts> void re(Ts &...ts) { Reader<cin>{}.read(ts...); }#define def(t, args...)                                                        \	t args;                                                                    \	re(args); template <auto &os, bool debug, bool print_nd> struct Writer {	string comma() const { return debug ? "," : ""; }	template <class T> constexpr char Space(const T &) const {		return print_nd && (Iterable<T>::value or IsTuple<T>::value) ? '
'		                                                             : ' ';	}	template <class T> void Impl(T const &t) const {		if constexpr (DefaultO<T>::value) os << t;		else if constexpr (Iterable<T>::value) {			if (debug) os << '{';			int i = 0;			for (auto &&x : t)				((i++) ? (os << comma() << Space(x), Impl(x)) : Impl(x));			if (debug) os << '}';		} else if constexpr (IsTuple<T>::value) {			if (debug) os << '(';			std::apply(			    [this](auto const &...args) {				    int i = 0;				    (((i++) ? (os << comma() << " ", Impl(args)) : Impl(args)),				     ...);			    },			    t);			if (debug) os << ')';		} else static_assert(IsTuple<T>::value, "No matching type for print");	}	template <class T> void ImplWrapper(T const &t) const {		if (debug) os << "\033[0;31m";		Impl(t);		if (debug) os << "\033[0m";	}	template <class... Ts> void print(Ts const &...ts) const {		((Impl(ts)), ...);	}	template <class F, class... Ts>	void print_with_sep(const std::string &sep, F const &f,	                    Ts const &...ts) const {		ImplWrapper(f), ((os << sep, ImplWrapper(ts)), ...), os << '
';	}	void print_with_sep(const std::string &) const { os << '
'; }}; template <class... Ts> void pr(Ts const &...ts) {	Writer<cout, false, true>{}.print(ts...);}template <class... Ts> void ps(Ts const &...ts) {	Writer<cout, false, true>{}.print_with_sep(" ", ts...);}}  // namespace IO inline namespace Debug {template <typename... Args> void err(Args... args) {	Writer<cerr, true, false>{}.print_with_sep(" | ", args...);}template <typename... Args> void errn(Args... args) {	Writer<cerr, true, true>{}.print_with_sep(" | ", args...);} void err_prefix(str func, int line, string args) {	cerr << "\033[0;31m[1mDEBUG\033[0m"	     << " | "	     << "[34m" << func << "\033[0m"	     << ":"	     << "[34m" << line << "\033[0m"	     << " - "	     << "[" << args << "] = ";} #ifdef LOCAL#define dbg(args...) err_prefix(__FUNCTION__, __LINE__, #args), err(args)#define dbgn(args...) err_prefix(__FUNCTION__, __LINE__, #args), errn(args)#else#define dbg(...)#define dbgn(args...)#endif const auto beg_time = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();// https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47980498/accurate-c-c-clock-on-a-multi-core-processor-with-auto-overclock?noredirect=1&lq=1double time_elapsed() {	return chrono::duration<double>(std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now() -	                                beg_time)	    .count();}}  // namespace Debug inline namespace FileIO {void setIn(str s) { freopen(s.c_str(), "r", stdin); }void setOut(str s) { freopen(s.c_str(), "w", stdout); }void setIO(str s = "") {	cin.tie(0)->sync_with_stdio(0);  // unsync C / C++ I/O streams	cout << fixed << setprecision(12);	// cin.exceptions(cin.failbit);	// throws exception when do smth illegal	// ex. try to read letter into int	if (sz(s)) setIn(s + ".in"), setOut(s + ".out");  // for old USACO}}  // namespace FileIO // make sure to intialize ALL GLOBAL VARS between tcs! int N, ones; /** * Description: Fast bipartite matching. * Time: $O(M\sqrt N)$ * Source: Own * Verification: https://old.yosupo.jp/problem/bipartitenxting */ vpi maxMatch(int L, int R, const vpi &edges) {	V<vi> adj = V<vi>(L);	vi nxt(L, -1), prv(R, -1), lev, ptr;	F0R(i, sz(edges)) adj.at(edges[i].f).pb(edges[i].s);	while (true) {		lev = ptr = vi(L);		int max_lev = 0;		queue<int> q;		F0R(i, L) if (nxt[i] == -1) lev[i] = 1, q.push(i);		while (sz(q)) {			int x = q.ft;			q.pop();			for (int y : adj[x]) {				int z = prv[y];				if (z == -1) max_lev = lev[x];				else if (!lev[z]) lev[z] = lev[x] + 1, q.push(z);			}			if (max_lev) break;		}		if (!max_lev) break;		F0R(i, L) if (lev[i] > max_lev) lev[i] = 0;		auto dfs = [&](auto self, int x) -> bool {			for (; ptr[x] < sz(adj[x]); ++ptr[x]) {				int y = adj[x][ptr[x]], z = prv[y];				if (z == -1 || (lev[z] == lev[x] + 1 && self(self, z)))					return nxt[x] = y, prv[y] = x, ptr[x] = sz(adj[x]), 1;			}			return 0;		};		F0R(i, L) if (nxt[i] == -1) dfs(dfs, i);	}	vpi ans;	F0R(i, L) if (nxt[i] != -1) ans.pb({i, nxt[i]});	return ans;} vpi get_match(str S, V<vi> adj) {	vpi edges;	F0R(i, sz(S)) if (S.at(i) == '1') {		for (int j : adj.at(i)) { edges.pb({i, j}); }	}	auto v = maxMatch(N, N, edges);	if (sz(v) != ones) return {};	return v;} /** * Description: Disjoint Set Union with path compression * and union by size. Add edges and test connectivity. * Use for Kruskal's or Boruvka's minimum spanning tree. * Time: O(\alpha(N)) * Source: CSAcademy, KACTL * Verification: * */ struct DSU {	vi e;	void init(int N) { e = vi(N, -1); }	int get(int x) { return e[x] < 0 ? x : e[x] = get(e[x]); }	bool sameSet(int a, int b) { return get(a) == get(b); }	int size(int x) { return -e[get(x)]; }	bool unite(int x, int y) {  // union by size		x = get(x), y = get(y);		if (x == y) return 0;		if (e[x] > e[y]) swap(x, y);		e[x] += e[y];		e[y] = x;		return 1;	}}; /**tcT> T kruskal(int N, vector<pair<T,pi>> ed) {    sort(all(ed));    T ans = 0; DSU D; D.init(N); // edges that unite are in MST    each(a,ed) if (D.unite(a.s.f,a.s.s)) ans += a.f;    return ans;}*/ bool allzero(vi v) {	each(t, v) if (t != 0) return 0;	return 1;} str transition(str S, vpi v) {	// dbg("TRANSITION", S, v);	assert(sz(v) == ones);	str nS(N, '0');	for (auto [x, y] : v) {		assert(S.at(x) == '1' && nS.at(y) == '0');		S.at(x) = '0';		nS.at(y) = '1';	}	return nS;} V<vpi> solve_even(str S, str T, vpi forest_matching, vpi forest_extra,                  int goal) {	vi other(2 * N, -1);	DSU D;	D.init(2 * N);	for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching) {		assert(other.at(x) == -1);		assert(other.at(y) == -1);		other.at(x) = y;		other.at(y) = x;		assert(D.unite(x, y));	}	for (auto [x, y] : forest_extra) { assert(D.unite(x, y)); } 	// dbg(S, T, forest_matching, forest_extra, goal);	F0R(i, N) if (S.at(i) == '1') assert(other.at(2 * i + 1) != -1);	F0R(i, N) if (T.at(i) == '1') assert(other.at(2 * i + 1) != -1);	V<set<int>> adj(2 * N);	auto ae = [&](int x, int y) {		assert(x % 2 == 0);		assert(y % 2 == 1);		adj.at(x).ins(y), adj.at(y).ins(x);	};	for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching) ae(x, y);	for (auto [x, y] : forest_extra) ae(x, y);	auto del_edge = [&](int x, int y) {		assert(adj.at(x).count(y) && adj.at(y).count(x));		adj.at(x).erase(y);		adj.at(y).erase(x);	};	V<vpi> ans(goal);	auto extract_shortest_path = [&](str &s, int odd_vert) -> vi {		vi par(2 * N, -1);		queue<int> q;		q.push(odd_vert);		par.at(odd_vert) = odd_vert;		while (true) {			int x = q.ft;			q.pop();			if (x % 2 == 1 && s.at(x / 2) == '1') {				s.at(x / 2) = '0';				vi path{x};				while (path.bk != odd_vert) path.pb(par.at(path.bk));				return path;			}			if (x % 2 == 0 && other.at(x) != -1 &&			    s.at(other.at(x) / 2) == '1') {				par.at(other.at(x)) = x;				x = other.at(x);				s.at(x / 2) = '0';				vi path{x};				while (path.bk != odd_vert) path.pb(par.at(path.bk));				return path;			}			// if (x % 2 == 0 && s.at())			for (int y : adj.at(x))				if (par.at(y) == -1) {					par.at(y) = x;					q.push(y);				}		}		assert(false);	};	int L = 0, R = goal;	while (true) {		assert(L <= R);		if (S == T) {			vpi match, rmatch;			for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching)				if (S.at(y / 2) == '1') {					rmatch.pb({y / 2, x / 2});					match.pb({x / 2, y / 2});				}			FOR(i, L, R) {				if (i % 2 == 0) {					ans.at(i).ins(end(ans.at(i)), all(rmatch));				} else {					ans.at(i).ins(end(ans.at(i)), all(match));				}			}			each(t, ans) assert(sz(t) == ones);			return ans;		}		bool flag = 0;		F0R(i, 2 * N) if (sz(adj.at(i)) == 1) {			int x = *begin(adj.at(i));			if (other.at(i) == -1) {				del_edge(i, x);				flag = true;				break;			}			assert(other.at(i) == x);			if (sz(adj.at(x)) == 2) {				int odd_vert = i % 2 == 1 ? i : x;				int even_vert = i ^ x ^ odd_vert;				if (S.at(odd_vert / 2) == '1') {					S.at(odd_vert / 2) = '0';					vi path = extract_shortest_path(T, odd_vert);					assert(sz(path) % 2 == 1);					assert(sz(path) - 1 <= R - L);					F0R(j, sz(path) - 1) {						assert(R - 1 - j >= L);						ans.at(R - 1 - j).pb(						    {path.at(j + 1) / 2, path.at(j) / 2});					}					FOR(j, sz(path) - 1, R - L) {						ans.at(R - 1 - j).pb(						    j % 2 == 0 ? pi{even_vert / 2, odd_vert / 2}						               : pi{odd_vert / 2, even_vert / 2});					}					for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching) {						assert(y % 2 == 1);						if (T.at(y / 2) == '1') {							ans.at(R - 2).pb({y / 2, x / 2});							ans.at(R - 1).pb({x / 2, y / 2});						}					}					R -= 2;				} else if (T.at(odd_vert / 2) == '1') {					T.at(odd_vert / 2) = '0';					vi path = extract_shortest_path(S, odd_vert);					assert(sz(path) % 2 == 1);					assert(sz(path) - 1 <= R - L);					F0R(j, sz(path) - 1) {						ans.at(L + j).pb({path.at(j) / 2, path.at(j + 1) / 2});					}					FOR(j, sz(path) - 1, R - L) {						if (j % 2 == 0) {  // starts with odd vert							ans.at(L + j).pb({odd_vert / 2, even_vert / 2});						} else {							ans.at(L + j).pb({even_vert / 2, odd_vert / 2});						}					}					for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching) {						assert(y % 2 == 1);						if (S.at(y / 2) == '1') {							ans.at(L).pb({y / 2, x / 2});							ans.at(L + 1).pb({x / 2, y / 2});						}					}					L += 2;				}				del_edge(i, x);				del_edge(x, *begin(adj.at(x)));				flag = true;				break;			}		}		if (!flag) {			dbg("OOPS", L, R, S, T);			dbg(forest_matching, forest_extra);			exit(0);		}		assert(flag);		continue;	}} optional<V<vpi>> solve_two_N_minus_one(V<vi> adj, str S, str T, vpi mS,                                       vpi mT) {	// dbg("START");	transition(S, mS);	transition(T, mT);	// dbg("EN"); 	{		DSU D;		D.init(2 * N);		vi balance(2 * N);		F0R(i, N) for (int j : adj.at(i)) D.unite(2 * i, 2 * j + 1);		F0R(i, N) if (S.at(i) == '1')++ balance.at(D.get(2 * i));		F0R(i, N) if (T.at(i) == '1')-- balance.at(D.get(2 * i + 1));		if (!allzero(balance)) return {};	} 	// dbg("TRYING", adj, S, T, mS, mT); 	V<vi> cyc_out(2 * N), cyc_in(2 * N);	auto directed = [&](int a, int b) {		// dbg("DIRECTED", a, b);		cyc_out.at(a).pb(b);		cyc_in.at(b).pb(a);	}; 	for (auto [x, y] : mS) directed(2 * x, 2 * y + 1);	for (auto [x, y] : mT) directed(2 * x + 1, 2 * y);	each(t, cyc_in) assert(sz(t) <= 1);	each(t, cyc_out) assert(sz(t) <= 1); 	vpi forest_matching;	auto add_matched_edge = [&](int x, int y) {		if (x % 2 != 0) swap(x, y);		assert(x % 2 == 0 && y % 2 == 1);		forest_matching.pb({x, y});	};	F0R(i, 2 * N) if (sz(cyc_out[i]) && !sz(cyc_in[i])) {		vi path{i};		while (sz(cyc_out[path.bk])) path.pb(cyc_out[path.bk].bk);		each(t, path) cyc_in[t].clear(), cyc_out[t].clear(); 		if (sz(path) % 2 == 1) path.pop_back(); 		F0R(j, sz(path) / 2)		add_matched_edge(path.at(2 * j), path.at(2 * j + 1));	}	F0R(i, 2 * N) if (i % 2 == 0 && (sz(cyc_in[i]) && sz(cyc_out[i]))) {		vi path{i};		while (true) {			assert(sz(cyc_out[path.bk]));			int nxt = cyc_out[path.bk].bk;			if (nxt == path.ft) break;			path.pb(nxt);		}		assert(sz(path) % 2 == 0);		each(t, path) cyc_in[t].clear(), cyc_out[t].clear();		F0R(j, sz(path) / 2)		add_matched_edge(path.at(2 * j), path.at(2 * j + 1));	}	each(t, cyc_in) assert(sz(t) == 0);	each(t, cyc_out) assert(sz(t) == 0); 	DSU D;	D.init(2 * N);	for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching) assert(D.unite(x, y));	vpi forest_extra;	F0R(i, N) for (int j : adj.at(i)) {		int a = 2 * i, b = 2 * j + 1;		if (D.unite(a, b)) forest_extra.pb({a, b});	}	vpi first_match;	for (auto [x, y] : forest_matching)		if (S.at(x / 2) == '1') first_match.pb({x / 2, y / 2});	S = transition(S, first_match);	auto ret = solve_even(S, T, forest_matching, forest_extra, 2 * N - 2);	ret.ins(begin(ret), first_match);	return ret;} str tran_all(str S, V<vpi> ans) {	each(t, ans) S = transition(S, t);	return S;} void finish(str S, str T, V<vpi> ans) {	ps("Yes");	assert(tran_all(S, ans) == T);	ps(sz(ans));	vi loc(N, -1);	V<vi> ans_vec;	ans_vec.eb();	F0R(i, N) if (S.at(i) == '1') {		loc.at(i) = sz(ans_vec.bk);		ans_vec.bk.pb(i);	}	each(t, ans) {		ans_vec.pb(vi(ones, -1));		vi nloc(N, -1);		for (auto [x, y] : t) {			nloc.at(y) = loc.at(x);			ans_vec.bk.at(nloc.at(y)) = y;		}		swap(loc, nloc);	} 	each(t, ans_vec) {		each(u, t)++ u;		ps(t);	}} void solve(int N_, int M, str orig_S, str orig_T, vpi edges) {	auto S = orig_S, T = orig_T;	N = N_; 	// dbg("TEST", N, M, S, T, edges); 	V<vi> adj(N);	for (auto [u, v] : edges) {		--u, --v;		adj.at(u).pb(v), adj.at(v).pb(u);	}	ones = 0;	each(t, S) ones += t == '1';	if (S == T) {		ps("Yes");		ps(0);		vi ans;		F0R(i, N) if (S[i] == '1') ans.pb(i + 1);		ps(ans);		return;	}	auto mS = get_match(orig_S, adj);	if (!sz(mS)) {		ps("No");		return;	}	auto mT = get_match(T, adj);	if (!sz(mT)) {		ps("No");		return;	}	auto ans1 = solve_two_N_minus_one(adj, S, T, mS, mT);	if (ans1.has_value()) return finish(orig_S, orig_T, ans1.value()); 	T = transition(T, mT);	for (auto &[x, y] : mT) swap(x, y); 	auto ans2 = solve_two_N_minus_one(adj, S, T, mS, mT);	if (ans2.has_value()) {		auto ans = ans2.value();		ans.pb(mT);		return finish(orig_S, orig_T, ans);	}	// dbg("OOP");	ps("No");} void solve(int tc) {	def(int, N);	def(int, M);	def(str, S);	def(str, T);	vpi edges(M);	re(edges);	solve(N, M, S, T, edges);} int main() {	setIO();	// FOR(N, 1, 10) {	// 	rep(100) {	// 		vpi edges;	// 		FOR(i, 1, N) FOR(j, i + 1, N + 1) if (rng() & 1) edges.pb({i, j});	// 		vi pos(N);	// 		iota(all(pos), 0);	// 		int c = rng() % (N + 1);	// 		str S(N, '0'), T(N, '0');	// 		shuffle(all(pos), rng);	// 		F0R(i, c) S.at(pos.at(i)) =
